titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Malcolm F. Birch family collection 2006.025
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:18:55 +0000.

did.abstract: This collection contains daguerreotypes, tintypes, stereo cards, cabinet cards, and studio cards produced by the photography studio of Silas Avery Holmes, as well as various other photographers. Subjects include family outings; Central Park; Petersburg, Saratoga, and Niagara Falls, N.Y.; Blackwell's Island (later Roosevelt Island); and New York City street scenes. Another set of photographs depicts members of the Holmes family, including Silas Avery Holmes.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Silas Avery Holmes (1819 or 20-1886) was a New York City photographer who was a contemporary of Matthew Brady. He operated five studios, one of which was located at 596 Broadway between Houston and Prince Streets. Another was at 303 Broadway between Duane and Reade Streets.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Malcolm F. Birch family collection, 2006.025, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains daguerreotypes, tintypes, stereo cards, cabinet cards, and studio cards produced by the photography studio of Silas Avery Holmes, as well as various other photographers. Subjects include family outings; Central Park; Petersburg, Saratoga, and Niagara Falls, N.Y.; Blackwell's Island (later Roosevelt Island); and New York City street scenes. Another set of photographs depicts members of the Holmes family, including Silas Avery Holmes.
